comment: Fairly classic Highland notes greet the nose honey floral with a hint a peat hiding in the background. The taste has a subtle honey sweetness with a big dry and subtle peat finish. A unique dram with peat from the Highlands a must try for any Scotch fan.

I would find this whisky hard to beat based on price and flavour. A delicate but rich smoky aroma gives a sense of warmth and comfort reminds me of the warm finish of a coal fire.

The taste is complex with the right mix of sweetness, toffee, honey and fruit along with the beautiful smoke running underneath.

The finish is long and warm without any uncomfortable burn, very easy to drink.
A very easy drinking, smokey dram. Lightly flavoured with a drying finish, making it difficult to put the cork back in. Enjoyable.

Earthy and smoky nose with a little honey. A quick, slick honey on the palate which gets swept away by an oily peat. A little grassy as well, very pleasant and easy to drink. Just the slightest hint of spice appears as you hold the whisky in your mouth and let it roll around. Mild sweet finish. 7/10, worth the price if you can get it under $30.
Not bad for 30 bucks. Light peat, mellow, floral. Light honey, warm, tasted neat, rocks and/or water unnecessary. Overall, solid budget scotch for a daily drink or 3.

Initially an aroma of lemon wedges covered in soot. There's also some lovely honeydew and sage. Tart and acidic palate up front. There's more citrus on the palate but I'm wanting cream to go along with it like in Glen Grant. The finish is herbaceous, dusted with soot, but short lived.

Budget single malt under $30 and peated too, sign me up. Poured neat, light color in glass. Nose has peat but its more of the medicinal bandaid variety. Some smoke too and olive brine. Dig deep and youll get malt, dusty cardboard and just a hint of orchard. Kinda mild but ok. Palate is malt with some smoke and char. Its a bit diluted at 80pf but what you get is decent flavor. Does make for an easy drinker. Finish is smoky with charred meat, some wood notes and far away malt. Islay lovers and hardcore peatheads can probably pass, this is more suited for a beginner. Lets be real though its still scotch with peat so its not bad in my book. Plus this is the malt that gives Teachers its smoke. Call it introductory peaty scotch that's good value for the $$...........81/100.......not a repurchase but if you've never had peat this is low cost option to get your feet wet. Still better than most blends

On the nose, some peat, pepper, dates, blackberry marmalade, vanilla, honey, freshly cut apples, and chocolate powder. Amazing.

On the palate is also a masterpiece: the word here is BALANCE. Ginger, wood in an elegant way, a little hot, a little spicy, a little ashy, some saltyness and a medium spicy aftertaste all wrapped up in a beatiful way.

Overall this is a 95 over 100, another of my top whiskies. If you are looking something to buy, buy Ardmore.
